question:
Of the eight students—George, Helen, Irving, Kyle, Lenore, Nina, Olivia, and Robert—in a seminar, exactly six will give individual oral reports during three consecutive days—Monday, Tuesday, and Wednesday. Exactly two reports will be given each day—one in the morning and one in the afternoon—according to the following conditions: Tuesday is the only day on which George can give a report. Neither Olivia nor Robert can give an afternoon report. If Nina gives a report, then on the next day Helen and Irving must both give reports, unless Nina's report is given on Wednesday.

Which one of the following could be the schedule of the students' reports?
A) Mon. morning: Helen; Mon. afternoon: Robert Tues. morning: Olivia; Tues. afternoon: Irving Wed. morning: Lenore; Wed. afternoon: Kyle
B) Mon. morning: Irving; Mon. afternoon: Olivia Tues. morning: Helen; Tues. afternoon: Kyle Wed. morning: Nina; Wed. afternoon: Lenore
C) Mon. morning: Lenore; Mon. afternoon: Helen Tues. morning: George; Tues. afternoon: Kyle Wed. morning: Robert; Wed. afternoon: Irving
D) Mon. morning: Nina; Mon. afternoon: Helen Tues. morning: Robert; Tues. afternoon: Irving Wed. morning: Olivia; Wed. afternoon: Lenore
E) Mon. morning: Olivia; Mon. afternoon: Nina Tues. morning: Irving; Tues. afternoon: Helen Wed. morning: Kyle; Wed. afternoon: George
chain_of_thought: The only constraint that matters is that George can only speak on Tuesday.  Nina's report leads to a chain reaction where Helen and Irving have to speak on the next day, unless Nina's report is given on Wednesday.  The remaining restrictions are not relevant to the order of reports.  The schedule must be in a way that fulfills all conditions.
full_output:
<think>The only constraint that matters is that George can only speak on Tuesday.  Nina's report leads to a chain reaction where Helen and Irving have to speak on the next day, unless Nina's report is given on Wednesday.  The remaining restrictions are not relevant to the order of reports.  The schedule must be in a way that fulfills all conditions.</think>
<ans>C</ans>

question:
Of the eight students—George, Helen, Irving, Kyle, Lenore, Nina, Olivia, and Robert—in a seminar, exactly six will give individual oral reports during three consecutive days—Monday, Tuesday, and Wednesday. Exactly two reports will be given each day—one in the morning and one in the afternoon—according to the following conditions: Tuesday is the only day on which George can give a report. Neither Olivia nor Robert can give an afternoon report. If Nina gives a report, then on the next day Helen and Irving must both give reports, unless Nina's report is given on Wednesday.

If Kyle and Lenore do not give reports, then the morning reports on Monday, Tuesday, and Wednesday, respectively, could be given by
A) Helen, George, and Nina
B) Irving, Robert, and Helen
C) Nina, Helen, and Olivia
D) Olivia, Robert, and Irving
E) Robert, George, and Helen
chain_of_thought: We know George can only give a report on Tuesday. Olivia and Robert cannot give afternoon reports. If Nina gives a report, then Helen and Irving must give reports. If Nina does not give a report, then Helen and Irving must both give reports.  If Kyle and Lenore do not give reports, then the reports on Monday, Tuesday, and Wednesday must be given by Nina, Helen, and Irving.
full_output:
<think>We know George can only give a report on Tuesday. Olivia and Robert cannot give afternoon reports. If Nina gives a report, then Helen and Irving must give reports. If Nina does not give a report, then Helen and Irving must both give reports.  If Kyle and Lenore do not give reports, then the reports on Monday, Tuesday, and Wednesday must be given by Nina, Helen, and Irving. </think>
<ans>C</ans>

question:
Of the eight students—George, Helen, Irving, Kyle, Lenore, Nina, Olivia, and Robert—in a seminar, exactly six will give individual oral reports during three consecutive days—Monday, Tuesday, and Wednesday. Exactly two reports will be given each day—one in the morning and one in the afternoon—according to the following conditions: Tuesday is the only day on which George can give a report. Neither Olivia nor Robert can give an afternoon report. If Nina gives a report, then on the next day Helen and Irving must both give reports, unless Nina's report is given on Wednesday.

If George, Nina, and Robert give reports and they do so on different days from one another, which one of the following could be true?
A) Helen gives a report on Wednesday.
B) Nina gives a report on Monday.
C) Nina gives a report on Tuesday.
D) Olivia gives a report on Monday.
E) Robert gives a report on Wednesday.
chain_of_thought: Nina's report must be given on Monday, and Helen and Irving must give reports on Tuesday. We know that George can only give a report on Tuesday, and neither Olivia nor Robert can give an afternoon report. So we can conclude that Nina gives a report on Monday, and Helen and Irving must give reports on Tuesday.
full_output:
<think>Nina's report must be given on Monday, and Helen and Irving must give reports on Tuesday. We know that George can only give a report on Tuesday, and neither Olivia nor Robert can give an afternoon report. So we can conclude that Nina gives a report on Monday, and Helen and Irving must give reports on Tuesday. </think>
<ans>C</ans>

question:
Of the eight students—George, Helen, Irving, Kyle, Lenore, Nina, Olivia, and Robert—in a seminar, exactly six will give individual oral reports during three consecutive days—Monday, Tuesday, and Wednesday. Exactly two reports will be given each day—one in the morning and one in the afternoon—according to the following conditions: Tuesday is the only day on which George can give a report. Neither Olivia nor Robert can give an afternoon report. If Nina gives a report, then on the next day Helen and Irving must both give reports, unless Nina's report is given on Wednesday.

If Kyle gives the afternoon report on Tuesday, and Helen gives the afternoon report on Wednesday, which one of the following could be the list of the students who give the morning reports on Monday, Tuesday, and Wednesday, respectively?
A) Irving, Lenore, and Nina
B) Lenore, George, and Irving
C) Nina, Irving, and Lenore
D) Robert, George, and Irving
E) Robert, Irving, and Lenore
chain_of_thought: George can only give a report on Tuesday. If Kyle gives the afternoon report on Tuesday, then Nina’s report must be on Monday. If Nina’s report is on Monday, then Helen and Irving must give reports on Tuesday. If Nina’s report is on Wednesday, then Helen and Irving must give reports on Tuesday. So, Nina, Irving, and Helen must give reports on Monday, Tuesday, and Wednesday, respectively.
full_output:
<think>George can only give a report on Tuesday. If Kyle gives the afternoon report on Tuesday, then Nina’s report must be on Monday. If Nina’s report is on Monday, then Helen and Irving must give reports on Tuesday. If Nina’s report is on Wednesday, then Helen and Irving must give reports on Tuesday. So, Nina, Irving, and Helen must give reports on Monday, Tuesday, and Wednesday, respectively.</think>
<ans>A</ans>
